j746-krni.Title: A is for Alexander B is for Bunyip C is for Canberra
j746-krni.Description:
Alexander Bunyip is a character from the popular 1972 children's book, The Monster that Ate Canberra by author and illustrator, Michael Salmon. In what became a series of books the bunyip is portrayed as a bemused adventurer who comes up with some novel uses for Canberra’s iconic landmarks. Anne Ross playfully shows the bunyip with his trusty travel case in hand heading out from a day in the national triangle. Cast by Perrin Sculpture Foundry

In what became a series of books the bunyip is portrayed as a bemused adventurer who comes up with some novel uses for Canberra’s iconic landmarks. Anne Ross playfully shows the bunyip with his trusty travel case in hand heading out from a day in the national triangle. Cast by Perrin Sculpture Foundry

j746-krni.Title: A Short Walk
j746-krni.Medium: Steel, highly polished concrete aggreage mixture hand seeded with textured and coloured broken tail light reflectors
j746-krni.Description: A landmark for the main turn into the Weston Creek Centre, A Short Walk consists of figure silhouettes of a big sister, little brother and little sister that derive from the pedestrian crossing sign. The grouping suggests friendship, family and community, while the incorporation of broken tail light reflectors betrays the artist’s longstanding concern with car culture and road safety issues.
j746-krni.pointname: A landmark for the main turn into the Weston Creek Centre, A Short Walk consists of figure silhouettes of a big sister, little brother and little sister that derive from the pedestrian crossing sign. The grouping suggests friendship, family and community, while the incorporation of broken tail light reflectors betrays the artist’s longstanding concern with car culture and road safety issues.

j746-krni.Title: ACT Bushfire Memorial
j746-krni.Artist: Tess Horwitz, Tony Steel and Martyn Jolly
j746-krni.Description: The ACT Bushfire Memorial was commissioned by the ACT Government to acknowledge the impact of the 2003 bushfires, to mark the process of recovery, and to thank the many organisations and individuals who played crucial roles in the fire fighting and recovery efforts.
j746-krni.pointname: The ACT Bushfire Memorial was commissioned by the ACT Government to acknowledge the impact of the 2003 bushfires, to mark the process of recovery, and to thank the many organisations and individuals who played crucial roles in the fire fighting and recovery efforts.

j746-krni.Title: ACT Memorial
j746-krni.Medium: Stainless steel, granite, optic fibres and lighting
j746-krni.Description: The ACT Memorial was commissioned by the ACT Government to honour all those people who have had an association with the ACT and who have served their country in war, conflict, peacekeeping and humanitarian missions.
j746-krni.pointname: The ACT Memorial was commissioned by the ACT Government to honour all those people who have had an association with the ACT and who have served their country in war, conflict, peacekeeping and humanitarian missions.

j746-krni.Title: Ainslie's Sheep
j746-krni.Description: The national capital has memorably been described as a good sheep paddock spoiled". This sculpture is a satirical salute to one of Canberra's early pastoralists - James Ainslie who came to the region in 1825."
j746-krni.pointname: The national capital has memorably been described as a good sheep paddock spoiled". This sculpture is a satirical salute to one of Canberra's early pastoralists - James Ainslie who came to the region in 1825."

j746-krni.Title: Alfred Deakin, A Life in Three Phases
j746-krni.Description: The artwork is a single bust, created from three separate heads that have been ‘cut’ into pieces and re-assembled, creating a work which is stable, robust and visually engaging from all angles. The three heads are representative of three distinct periods of Alfred Deakin’s life:
j746-krni.pointtype: Alfred Deakin, A Life in Three Phases
j746-krni.pointname: The artwork is a single bust, created from three separate heads that have been ‘cut’ into pieces and re-assembled, creating a work which is stable, robust and visually engaging from all angles. The three heads are representative of three distinct periods of Alfred Deakin’s life:

j746-krni.Title: Angel Wings
j746-krni.Medium: Wind activated kinetic sculpture, heat cured epoxy glass, carbon
j746-krni.Description: Angel Wings has been described by New Zealand sculptor, Phil Price as a celebration of being alive. “It brings together the enjoyment of being outside in the environment, movement and colour – all the simple things,” he says. The aerodynamic wings move in response to the wind. The 10 metre tall sculpture uses fully-sealed rolling bearing systems designed for longevity and environmental resilience.
j746-krni.pointname: Angel Wings has been described by New Zealand sculptor, Phil Price as a celebration of being alive. “It brings together the enjoyment of being outside in the environment, movement and colour – all the simple things,” he says. The aerodynamic wings move in response to the wind. The 10 metre tall sculpture uses fully-sealed rolling bearing systems designed for longevity and environmental resilience.

j746-krni.Title: Aquila
j746-krni.Description: Aquila is a sculptural arrangement of positive and negative shapes. A careful balance of form is revealed as you move around the sculpture. Aquila in Greek Mythology is the constellation of the eagle, a wide-winged soaring bird which carried the thunderbolts of Zeus.
j746-krni.pointname: Aquila is a sculptural arrangement of positive and negative shapes. A careful balance of form is revealed as you move around the sculpture. Aquila in Greek Mythology is the constellation of the eagle, a wide-winged soaring bird which carried the thunderbolts of Zeus.

j746-krni.Title: Ark in the Ark and Beyond
j746-krni.Description: Two arks have been carved out of a single piece of white granite and the addition of water creates this beautiful floating ark within an ark. The artist's inspiration originates from the Iwafune Shrine in Osaka - a massive, boat-shaped, traditional Shinto rock shrine.
j746-krni.pointtype: Ark in the Ark and Beyond
j746-krni.pointname: Two arks have been carved out of a single piece of white granite and the addition of water creates this beautiful floating ark within an ark. The artist's inspiration originates from the Iwafune Shrine in Osaka - a massive, boat-shaped, traditional Shinto rock shrine.

j746-krni.Title: Bogong Moths
j746-krni.Description: These large bogong moths are based on a design by Ngunnawal artist Jim Williams and are located between the National Museum of Australia and the Australian Institute for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Studies.
j746-krni.pointname: These large bogong moths are based on a design by Ngunnawal artist Jim Williams and are located between the National Museum of Australia and the Australian Institute for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Studies.

j746-krni.Title: bush pack (nil tenure)
j746-krni.Description: A series of seven life-size dogs in City Walk running the three groups towards the Civic Carousel. The dogs symbolise the intersection and tensions between the wild and domestic, the rural and the urban space and animals and humans.
j746-krni.pointname: A series of seven life-size dogs in City Walk running the three groups towards the Civic Carousel. The dogs symbolise the intersection and tensions between the wild and domestic, the rural and the urban space and animals and humans.

j746-krni.Title: Casuarina Pods
j746-krni.Description: In a gully where a creek used to run, three overgrown Casuarina seed pods appear to have dropped out of a grove of Casuarina trees and to be rolling down the grassy slope. At night the seed pods are lit from within by a gentle fibre optic light.
j746-krni.pointname: In a gully where a creek used to run, three overgrown Casuarina seed pods appear to have dropped out of a grove of Casuarina trees and to be rolling down the grassy slope. At night the seed pods are lit from within by a gentle fibre optic light.

j746-krni.Title: Centricity
j746-krni.Medium: Etched glass panels and fibre optic light
j746-krni.Description: Centricity contains three elements situated in Civic Square, an adjoining stairwell and the entrance to the Craft ACT gallery. Ripple refers to ripples of influence, Fingerprint refers to the materiality of craft and the concentric pattern of Canberra’s unique city plan and Crucible, a showcase featuring changing exhibitions.
j746-krni.pointname: Centricity contains three elements situated in Civic Square, an adjoining stairwell and the entrance to the Craft ACT gallery. Ripple refers to ripples of influence, Fingerprint refers to the materiality of craft and the concentric pattern of Canberra’s unique city plan and Crucible, a showcase featuring changing exhibitions.

j746-krni.Title: Chalchiuhtlicue
j746-krni.Aquisition Details: Donated by Mission Foods subsidiary of Gruma Corp and the Government of Mexico.
j746-krni.Description: Chalchiuhtlicue is inspired by the pre-Hispanic stone sculpture of the same name, found at the archaeological site of Teotihuacan, Mexico.
j746-krni.pointname: Chalchiuhtlicue is inspired by the pre-Hispanic stone sculpture of the same name, found at the archaeological site of Teotihuacan, Mexico.

j746-krni.Title: Choice of Passage
j746-krni.Description: This sculpture uses abstract forms to create a sense of balance and poise. The columns create an archway, or passage, that could be a starting or finishing point. Choice of Passage is a part of a series of large-scale artworks created with public space and public interaction in mind.
j746-krni.pointname: This sculpture uses abstract forms to create a sense of balance and poise. The columns create an archway, or passage, that could be a starting or finishing point. Choice of Passage is a part of a series of large-scale artworks created with public space and public interaction in mind.

j746-krni.Title: Circuitry
j746-krni.Description: This work is a red tower-like form constructed from an interlocking network of shapes based on a simplified human figure. The sculpture symbolises the dynamic flows of people, transport and information that fill, move though, and empty from the circulatory system of the city.
j746-krni.pointname: This work is a red tower-like form constructed from an interlocking network of shapes based on a simplified human figure. The sculpture symbolises the dynamic flows of people, transport and information that fill, move though, and empty from the circulatory system of the city.

j746-krni.Title: Civic Carousel
j746-krni.Description: The Civic Carousel commenced operation at the St Kilda Esplanade in Melbourne in 1915. It was designed and built by Herbert Thompson, designer of Australia’s first successful motor car. The outside of the carousel roof is adorned with paintings of horses, elephants and tigers, whilst inside are paintings of more contemplative scenes.
j746-krni.pointname: The Civic Carousel commenced operation at the St Kilda Esplanade in Melbourne in 1915. It was designed and built by Herbert Thompson, designer of Australia’s first successful motor car. The outside of the carousel roof is adorned with paintings of horses, elephants and tigers, whilst inside are paintings of more contemplative scenes.

j746-krni.Title: Civic Memory Quilt
j746-krni.Artist: Urban Art Projects (Floor Design) and Mary Hutchinson (writer)
j746-krni.Medium: Aluminium cores, plaques and sandblasted paving
j746-krni.Description: The quilt-like image of this work references Canberra’s Aboriginal and European cultural and natural history. The design features the Molonglo River, the bogong moth, kangaroo grass and oral histories. It also includes reminiscences by Paul McDermott from the celebrated comedy troupe 'The Doug Anthony All Stars' who busked on the site in the late 1980s.
j746-krni.pointname: The quilt-like image of this work references Canberra’s Aboriginal and European cultural and natural history. The design features the Molonglo River, the bogong moth, kangaroo grass and oral histories. It also includes reminiscences by Paul McDermott from the celebrated comedy troupe 'The Doug Anthony All Stars' who busked on the site in the late 1980s.

j746-krni.Title: Commemoration
j746-krni.Description: This work is dedicated to the volunteers and torch bearers who contributed to the 2000 Olympic and Paralympic games in Canberra.
j746-krni.pointname: This work is dedicated to the volunteers and torch bearers who contributed to the 2000 Olympic and Paralympic games in Canberra.

j746-krni.Title: Crossing
j746-krni.Description: The Coranderrk Street bridge forms a gateway from the Canberra Institute of Technology to the city. Crossing, which is located on the bridge pillars, symbolises the flow of energy generated by traffic, both pedestrian and vehicular. This artwork is best viewed at night.
j746-krni.pointname: The Coranderrk Street bridge forms a gateway from the Canberra Institute of Technology to the city. Crossing, which is located on the bridge pillars, symbolises the flow of energy generated by traffic, both pedestrian and vehicular. This artwork is best viewed at night.

j746-krni.Title: Culture Fragment
j746-krni.Medium: 100mm copper elbows and pipe, filled with cement grout
j746-krni.Description: By weaving the elements of his work together, David explores individual threads that collectively produce a “social fabric”. As a community we are all connected, our sense of separateness is only a question of degree.
j746-krni.pointname: By weaving the elements of his work together, David explores individual threads that collectively produce a “social fabric”. As a community we are all connected, our sense of separateness is only a question of degree.

j746-krni.Title: Cumulus Aeronauticus
j746-krni.Description: This artwork suggests movement of planes, people and celestial navigation.
j746-krni.pointname: This artwork suggests movement of planes, people and celestial navigation.

j746-krni.Title: Cushion
j746-krni.Medium: Stainless steel, polished granite wedge" plinth steel inlayed poetry pages"
j746-krni.Description: People can often be seen lounging in this large stainless steel cushion which is one of the most popular artworks in the city centre. A poem by Marion Halligan lies on on scattered pages on the granite plinth below the cushion to form a tribute to Garema Place.
j746-krni.pointname: People can often be seen lounging in this large stainless steel cushion which is one of the most popular artworks in the city centre. A poem by Marion Halligan lies on on scattered pages on the granite plinth below the cushion to form a tribute to Garema Place.

j746-krni.Title: Dancers on a Lakefront
j746-krni.Description: Dancers on a Lakefront draws inspiration from the native reeds and rushes that stretch along the perimeter of Lake Ginninderra.
j746-krni.pointname: Dancers on a Lakefront draws inspiration from the native reeds and rushes that stretch along the perimeter of Lake Ginninderra.

j746-krni.Title: Decollete
j746-krni.Description: This work was initially designed for the entryway to the Tuggeranong Arts Centre. It resembles a ships bow and wave reflecting the riverside location and nautical references in the design of the Arts Centre. The work was intended to pull the building’s flat façade into the street's pedestrian space. Following changes to the Arts Centre's entryway the artwork was moved to Manning Clarke Offices, Tuggeranong in 2000.
j746-krni.pointname: This work was initially designed for the entryway to the Tuggeranong Arts Centre. It resembles a ships bow and wave reflecting the riverside location and nautical references in the design of the Arts Centre. The work was intended to pull the building’s flat façade into the street's pedestrian space. Following changes to the Arts Centre's entryway the artwork was moved to Manning Clarke Offices, Tuggeranong in 2000.

j746-krni.Title: Dinornis Maximus
j746-krni.Description: Dinornis maximus is a prominent 11 metre tall wind-activated kinetic sculpture. The artwork forms a striking gateway on the northern edge of Woden Town Centre. The sculpture uses fully-sealed rolling bearing systems designed for longevity and environmental resilience to create 'a wind powered ballet in the sky'. In describing his artworks New Zealand artist Phil Price says he seeks a 'combination of movement that provides a flow and a dance'.
j746-krni.pointname: Dinornis maximus is a prominent 11 metre tall wind-activated kinetic sculpture. The artwork forms a striking gateway on the northern edge of Woden Town Centre. The sculpture uses fully-sealed rolling bearing systems designed for longevity and environmental resilience to create 'a wind powered ballet in the sky'. In describing his artworks New Zealand artist Phil Price says he seeks a 'combination of movement that provides a flow and a dance'.

j746-krni.Title: DNA
j746-krni.Description: The sculpture consists of 27 interconnected cubes. 26 are made from corten steel and one from mirrored stainless steel. The rusted elements blend together with the surrounding bushland setting while the single mirrored element reflects the presence of the viewer within the work. All 27 cubes combined would form a united cube with a ratio of 3:3.
j746-krni.pointname: The sculpture consists of 27 interconnected cubes. 26 are made from corten steel and one from mirrored stainless steel. The rusted elements blend together with the surrounding bushland setting while the single mirrored element reflects the presence of the viewer within the work. All 27 cubes combined would form a united cube with a ratio of 3:3.

j746-krni.Title: Dream Lens for the Future
j746-krni.Description: Oushi Zokei, Dream Lens for the Future, by Keizo Ushio is a circular granite form carved from one piece of stone. The work is positioned creating a view of City Hill looking through the centre.
j746-krni.pointname: Oushi Zokei, Dream Lens for the Future, by Keizo Ushio is a circular granite form carved from one piece of stone. The work is positioned creating a view of City Hill looking through the centre.

j746-krni.Title: Dreaming
j746-krni.Medium: Cast bronze figure on natural rock in rectangular pool
j746-krni.Description: This work was presented to the people of Canberra by the Reserve Bank of Australia.
j746-krni.pointname: This work was presented to the people of Canberra by the Reserve Bank of Australia.

j746-krni.Title: Droplet
j746-krni.Description: Droplet is a familiar geometric shape, classical in its simplicity, which references a drop of water.
j746-krni.pointname: Droplet is a familiar geometric shape, classical in its simplicity, which references a drop of water.

j746-krni.Title: Ebb and Flow
j746-krni.Description: The tall mirrored forms of Ebb and Flow draw in and reflect back the movement and colour of one of Canberra's busiest urban streets. The sculpture appears to be made of liquid and light. It floats stationary, offering a moment of reflection amidst the busy stream of the day.
j746-krni.pointname: The tall mirrored forms of Ebb and Flow draw in and reflect back the movement and colour of one of Canberra's busiest urban streets. The sculpture appears to be made of liquid and light. It floats stationary, offering a moment of reflection amidst the busy stream of the day.

j746-krni.Title: Egle Queen of Serpents
j746-krni.Description: This work refers to a Lithuanian folk tale about Egle, a woman who married the king of sea serpents.
j746-krni.pointname: This work refers to a Lithuanian folk tale about Egle, a woman who married the king of sea serpents.

j746-krni.Title: Eternity
j746-krni.Medium: Polished bronze ring and black painted steel
j746-krni.Description: This sculpture is said to symbolize the sculptor’s faith in the future of mankind. It was cast in Italy and donated to the people of Canberra by an anonymous donor in 1981.
j746-krni.pointname: This sculpture is said to symbolize the sculptor’s faith in the future of mankind. It was cast in Italy and donated to the people of Canberra by an anonymous donor in 1981.

j746-krni.Title: Ethos
j746-krni.Description: Ethos was the first work of art commissioned by the National Capital Development Commission (NCDC) for a public place in Canberra and was co-sponsored by the Canberra Chamber of Commerce. The work is listed on the ACT Heritage Objects Register.
j746-krni.pointname: Ethos was the first work of art commissioned by the National Capital Development Commission (NCDC) for a public place in Canberra and was co-sponsored by the Canberra Chamber of Commerce. The work is listed on the ACT Heritage Objects Register.

j746-krni.Title: Father and Son
j746-krni.Medium: Bronze figures in fountain with marble and tile basin
j746-krni.Description: This artwork was presented to the people of Canberra by the Hon. Alex Downer in memory of his father Sir John Downer. Originally installed in 1964, it was restored and relocated in Garema Place with a new marble base in 1986.
j746-krni.pointname: This artwork was presented to the people of Canberra by the Hon. Alex Downer in memory of his father Sir John Downer. Originally installed in 1964, it was restored and relocated in Garema Place with a new marble base in 1986.

j746-krni.Title: Fenix 2
j746-krni.Description: Fenix 2 is a replica of the capsule that rescued 33 trapped miners from the San Jose mine in the Atacama Desert, Chile in October 2010.
j746-krni.pointname: Fenix 2 is a replica of the capsule that rescued 33 trapped miners from the San Jose mine in the Atacama Desert, Chile in October 2010.

j746-krni.Title: Fireline
j746-krni.Description: At night Fireline’s flickering flames travel from its starting point at the front of Civic Square. Civic Square was built on grasslands which the traditional owners managed by fire. This work acknowledges the relationship of the Ngunnawal people to the region.
j746-krni.pointname: At night Fireline’s flickering flames travel from its starting point at the front of Civic Square. Civic Square was built on grasslands which the traditional owners managed by fire. This work acknowledges the relationship of the Ngunnawal people to the region.

j746-krni.Title: Folding Ground Across the In Between
j746-krni.Description: A folded form balanced on a point, painted red, and sitting opposite the partner piece 'sky shard above the in between', the artwork amplifies and gives form to the architectural forms of the building on one side and of the sculpture and the natural forms of the trees on the other.
j746-krni.pointtype: Folding Ground Across the In Between
j746-krni.pointname: A folded form balanced on a point, painted red, and sitting opposite the partner piece 'sky shard above the in between', the artwork amplifies and gives form to the architectural forms of the building on one side and of the sculpture and the natural forms of the trees on the other.

j746-krni.Title: Fractal Weave
j746-krni.Description: Fractal Weave is made from two woven curved forms in copper piping and sits on the pedestal in front of the Canberra Theatre and the Civic Library. The sculpture has been described as a physical and symbolic manifestation of the interrelated aspects of our diverse culture and heritage.
j746-krni.pointname: Fractal Weave is made from two woven curved forms in copper piping and sits on the pedestal in front of the Canberra Theatre and the Civic Library. The sculpture has been described as a physical and symbolic manifestation of the interrelated aspects of our diverse culture and heritage.

j746-krni.Title: Fused Glass
j746-krni.Description: This work was designed for the ACT Legislative Assembly foyer. The artist states that Colour is used as a universal language to convey a sense of energy and force associated with this place of decision making...." (Klaus Moje, 1998)."
j746-krni.pointname: This work was designed for the ACT Legislative Assembly foyer. The artist states that Colour is used as a universal language to convey a sense of energy and force associated with this place of decision making...." (Klaus Moje, 1998)."

j746-krni.Title: Gather
j746-krni.Description: These sculptures mark the entry to a popular Canberra shopping and cafe precinct - Manuka. They appear as a group of surreal vegetative forms crowned with oversized seed pods (referencing nearby Liquidamber trees).
j746-krni.pointname: These sculptures mark the entry to a popular Canberra shopping and cafe precinct - Manuka. They appear as a group of surreal vegetative forms crowned with oversized seed pods (referencing nearby Liquidamber trees).

j746-krni.Title: Gathering Place
j746-krni.Medium: Wood, stone, ceramic tiles and gravel
j746-krni.Description: This work contributes to a recreational and ceremonial place that is intended to encourage a locally-focussed, ongoing process of reconciliation between Aboriginal and non–Aboriginal people in the region. The four poles in the centre of the work are aligned with cardinal points: Ngunnawal to the East; Coming Together to the South; Reconciliation to the West and the Future, crowned by a wedge tailed eagle, to the North.
j746-krni.pointname: This work contributes to a recreational and ceremonial place that is intended to encourage a locally-focussed, ongoing process of reconciliation between Aboriginal and non–Aboriginal people in the region. The four poles in the centre of the work are aligned with cardinal points: Ngunnawal to the East; Coming Together to the South; Reconciliation to the West and the Future, crowned by a wedge tailed eagle, to the North.

j746-krni.Title: Gravity Circle
j746-krni.Description: Gravity Circle consists of a series of bold geometric forms arranged to evoke a feeling of carefully balanced energy or poise. The artwork's brushed stainless steel and bright crimson finish alludes to an elemental purity or essence. The large central element of the artwork balances across a narrow edge and references the scales of justice in the setting of the ACT Magistrate's Court.
j746-krni.pointname: Gravity Circle consists of a series of bold geometric forms arranged to evoke a feeling of carefully balanced energy or poise. The artwork's brushed stainless steel and bright crimson finish alludes to an elemental purity or essence. The large central element of the artwork balances across a narrow edge and references the scales of justice in the setting of the ACT Magistrate's Court.

j746-krni.Title: Gungahlin Drive Extension Artworks
j746-krni.Description: The objectives of the Gungahlin Drive Extension Public Art Program were to enhance the driving/riding experience and respond to the characteristics of the urban, natural and community environments.
j746-krni.pointname: The objectives of the Gungahlin Drive Extension Public Art Program were to enhance the driving/riding experience and respond to the characteristics of the urban, natural and community environments.

j746-krni.Title: Habitat
j746-krni.Description: This group of nine sculptures sensitively portray a range of animals that are endemic to the ACT. Acorns are included as a playful reference to Ainslie's well established oak trees. Habitat reflects on this area's close proximity to the Mount Ainslie Nature Reserve and the daily experience of seeing native wildlife interact with an exotic treescape.
j746-krni.pointname: This group of nine sculptures sensitively portray a range of animals that are endemic to the ACT. Acorns are included as a playful reference to Ainslie's well established oak trees. Habitat reflects on this area's close proximity to the Mount Ainslie Nature Reserve and the daily experience of seeing native wildlife interact with an exotic treescape.

j746-krni.Title: Harmonies
j746-krni.Description: Harmonies is a sculptural site marker that pays homage to Australia’s musical heritage by celebrating Dame Nellie Melba.
j746-krni.pointname: Harmonies is a sculptural site marker that pays homage to Australia’s musical heritage by celebrating Dame Nellie Melba.

j746-krni.Title: Here and Now
j746-krni.Description: Comprising eight figures made of an architectural steel mesh, installed in a group of three and a group of five. Dynamic moire patterns are created through the layering of mesh and light.
j746-krni.pointname: Comprising eight figures made of an architectural steel mesh, installed in a group of three and a group of five. Dynamic moire patterns are created through the layering of mesh and light.

j746-krni.Title: Honey Eater Rising
j746-krni.Description: This artwork depicts the Honey Eater bird rising up over the water at Billabong Park in North Watson.
j746-krni.pointname: This artwork depicts the Honey Eater bird rising up over the water at Billabong Park in North Watson.

j746-krni.Title: House Proud
j746-krni.Description: Crowning the circular Playhouse theatre, this blue and white neon word game is one of Canberra’s highest profile public artworks. A series of words precede the word ‘house’.
j746-krni.pointname: Crowning the circular Playhouse theatre, this blue and white neon word game is one of Canberra’s highest profile public artworks. A series of words precede the word ‘house’.

j746-krni.Title: Icarus
j746-krni.Description: These four bronze figures are inspired by the ancient Greek myth of Icarus. In this story Icarus' father, Daedalus, created wings made from feathers and wax for himself and his son to flee from captivity on the island of Crete. Icarus is warned by his father not to fly too close to the sun or the sea. However, exhilarated by the experience of flight Icarus flies too high, his waxen wings melt and he falls to his death. Brown's sculpture encourages sympathy with Icarus' unbridled exuberance and an acceptance of its ineveitable tragic consequences.
j746-krni.pointname: These four bronze figures are inspired by the ancient Greek myth of Icarus. In this story Icarus' father, Daedalus, created wings made from feathers and wax for himself and his son to flee from captivity on the island of Crete. Icarus is warned by his father not to fly too close to the sun or the sea. However, exhilarated by the experience of flight Icarus flies too high, his waxen wings melt and he falls to his death. Brown's sculpture encourages sympathy with Icarus' unbridled exuberance and an acceptance of its ineveitable tragic consequences.

j746-krni.Title: Illumicube
j746-krni.Description: This work was presented to the people of Canberra to commemorate 25 years of electricity supply. The colour of the light originally changed in response to sound. With more people now living in the city centre, the sound feature has been de-activated to stop the cacophony of car horns late at night.
j746-krni.pointname: This work was presented to the people of Canberra to commemorate 25 years of electricity supply. The colour of the light originally changed in response to sound. With more people now living in the city centre, the sound feature has been de-activated to stop the cacophony of car horns late at night.

j746-krni.Title: Kambah Firestorm Storytree Memorial
j746-krni.Artist: Bryan Carrick and Mount Taylor Estate community
j746-krni.Description: The Kambah Firestorm Storytree commemorates the bushfire that hit the Mount Taylor Estate community on 18 January 2003.
j746-krni.pointname: The Kambah Firestorm Storytree commemorates the bushfire that hit the Mount Taylor Estate community on 18 January 2003.

j746-krni.Title: Lady With Flowers
j746-krni.Description: A figurative bronze animated by a whimsical naivety that will touch the child in people of all ages, Lady With Flowers is located near a bus stop on Flemington Road, Gungahlin and one imagines she is about to take an ACTION bus to the City to meet her bronze counterpart, the Big Little Man.
j746-krni.pointname: A figurative bronze animated by a whimsical naivety that will touch the child in people of all ages, Lady With Flowers is located near a bus stop on Flemington Road, Gungahlin and one imagines she is about to take an ACTION bus to the City to meet her bronze counterpart, the Big Little Man.

j746-krni.Title: Laserwrap
j746-krni.Medium: 20 x 120 meter 532nm (green) lasers with 30-degree spreader lenses in motorised projector boxes
j746-krni.Description: Laserwrap projects a dynamic matrix of light onto the ACT Health Building. Transformed by the shifting laser light the concrete building appears to gently shift in its moorings. The work is activated approximately one hour after sunset.
j746-krni.pointname: Laserwrap projects a dynamic matrix of light onto the ACT Health Building. Transformed by the shifting laser light the concrete building appears to gently shift in its moorings. The work is activated approximately one hour after sunset.

j746-krni.Title: Life boat/Thuyen Cuu Roi
j746-krni.Description: Life Boat/Thuyen Cuu Roi is constructed from an old wooden boat which came from Hoi An in Vietnam. The arms/oars are carved from recycled timber and coated with lacquer using traditional Vietnamese techniques. In the artist's words Life Boat/Thuyen Cuu Roi seeks to embody ocean journeys of courage and compassion"."
j746-krni.pointname: Life Boat/Thuyen Cuu Roi is constructed from an old wooden boat which came from Hoi An in Vietnam. The arms/oars are carved from recycled timber and coated with lacquer using traditional Vietnamese techniques. In the artist's words Life Boat/Thuyen Cuu Roi seeks to embody ocean journeys of courage and compassion"."

j746-krni.Title: Life Cycle
j746-krni.Description: Life Cycle employs the basic materials of stone and steel to create a form that is both supple and organic. The double spiral of tightly packed stones is a visual metaphor for a life crammed full of experience. Through his work the sculptor uses elemental materials and abstract geometry to explore spiritual and cosmic concepts.
j746-krni.pointname: Life Cycle employs the basic materials of stone and steel to create a form that is both supple and organic. The double spiral of tightly packed stones is a visual metaphor for a life crammed full of experience. Through his work the sculptor uses elemental materials and abstract geometry to explore spiritual and cosmic concepts.

j746-krni.Title: Living Space
j746-krni.Artist: KunstForce (Angela Dufty and Geoffrey Farquhar Still)
j746-krni.Medium: Welded and painted metal, existing metal strap benches
j746-krni.Description: Living Space was part of 'Domain II' a series of temporary artworks commissioned from artists with an association with the ANU School of Art.
j746-krni.pointname: Living Space was part of 'Domain II' a series of temporary artworks commissioned from artists with an association with the ANU School of Art.

j746-krni.Title: Longitude
j746-krni.Description: Longitude is a figurative artwork in keeping with the established themes and uses of Veterans Park. The artsist takes up the concept of emotional separation that service personnel and their families experience during periods of active duty, a theme suggested during the community consultation.
j746-krni.pointname: Longitude is a figurative artwork in keeping with the established themes and uses of Veterans Park. The artsist takes up the concept of emotional separation that service personnel and their families experience during periods of active duty, a theme suggested during the community consultation.

j746-krni.Title: Mal Meninga
j746-krni.Description: This sculpture signifies the outstanding contribution Mal Meninga AM has made to Rugby League.
j746-krni.pointname: This sculpture signifies the outstanding contribution Mal Meninga AM has made to Rugby League.

j746-krni.Title: Microscopia
j746-krni.Description: Microscopia is a large scale wall mounted artwork made of glass and light.
j746-krni.pointname: Microscopia is a large scale wall mounted artwork made of glass and light.

j746-krni.Title: Moai
j746-krni.Medium: Carved from an unseasoned radiata pine log
j746-krni.Description: The figure represents an Easter Island stone Moai and was carved during the 1998 Multicultural Festival as a collaboration between artists from Easter Island and Australia.
j746-krni.pointname: The figure represents an Easter Island stone Moai and was carved during the 1998 Multicultural Festival as a collaboration between artists from Easter Island and Australia.

j746-krni.Title: Mohandas Karamchand Gandhi
j746-krni.Description: A tribute to Gandhi, the apostle of non violence (Ahisma) and truth (Satyagrah)". This sculpture lists Gandhi’s guildelines including  "No politics without principles; no commerce without morality; and no science without humanity.""
j746-krni.pointname: A tribute to Gandhi, the apostle of non violence (Ahisma) and truth (Satyagrah)". This sculpture lists Gandhi’s guildelines including  "No politics without principles; no commerce without morality; and no science without humanity.""

j746-krni.Title: Moth Ascending the Capital
j746-krni.Description: Moth Ascending the Capital is a sculptural work by Alexander Knox designed to evoke the image of a bogong moth bursting into flight.
j746-krni.pointname: Moth Ascending the Capital is a sculptural work by Alexander Knox designed to evoke the image of a bogong moth bursting into flight.

j746-krni.Title: Narrabundah: A Site Marker
j746-krni.Description: The artists have created an ambient seating area with mosaic like tile inserts and a metal weather vane of a hawk, the sun and the moon. The work refers to the suburb's name of 'Narrabundah' a local aboriginal name for 'small hawk'.
j746-krni.pointname: The artists have created an ambient seating area with mosaic like tile inserts and a metal weather vane of a hawk, the sun and the moon. The work refers to the suburb's name of 'Narrabundah' a local aboriginal name for 'small hawk'.

j746-krni.Title: Nest III
j746-krni.Description: Nest III is made from welded steel found objects. It depicts an eagle sitting upon a nest over a rocky outcrop.
j746-krni.pointname: Nest III is made from welded steel found objects. It depicts an eagle sitting upon a nest over a rocky outcrop.

j746-krni.Title: New Blood (Gateway Artwork)
j746-krni.Description: New Blood is a welcoming and dynamic gateway to Kippax Library, it celebrates energy, movement and colour.
j746-krni.pointname: New Blood is a welcoming and dynamic gateway to Kippax Library, it celebrates energy, movement and colour.

j746-krni.Title: On the Road Again
j746-krni.Description: By Melbourne-based artist and dog-lover Anne Ross, On the Road Again is a surreal take on life in the suburbs. The figure and canine companion are depicted driving up to the shops, only the car is missing.
j746-krni.pointname: By Melbourne-based artist and dog-lover Anne Ross, On the Road Again is a surreal take on life in the suburbs. The figure and canine companion are depicted driving up to the shops, only the car is missing.

j746-krni.Title: On the Staircase
j746-krni.Description: This bronze and copper sculpture contrasts a series of small human forms with the architectural weight of an oversized staircase. The artwork has a philosophical aspect by reflecting on the effect of reading on the spirit - 'the more I read the smaller I feel'.
j746-krni.pointname: This bronze and copper sculpture contrasts a series of small human forms with the architectural weight of an oversized staircase. The artwork has a philosophical aspect by reflecting on the effect of reading on the spirit - 'the more I read the smaller I feel'.

j746-krni.Title: Owl
j746-krni.Description: This landmark sculpture honours the Powerful Owl, Ninox strenua, which is the largest owl species in Australasia. The owl is classified as an occasional resident to the ACT and has been sighted in the Australian National Botanic Gardens, Canberra Nature Park and Namadgi National Park. The owl has a commanding and enigmatic presence when encountered in the wild. The artist has portrayed the owl as a guardian spirit or totem overlooking its domain.
j746-krni.pointname: This landmark sculpture honours the Powerful Owl, Ninox strenua, which is the largest owl species in Australasia. The owl is classified as an occasional resident to the ACT and has been sighted in the Australian National Botanic Gardens, Canberra Nature Park and Namadgi National Park. The owl has a commanding and enigmatic presence when encountered in the wild. The artist has portrayed the owl as a guardian spirit or totem overlooking its domain.

j746-krni.Title: Oyster
j746-krni.Description: Oyster is one of two indoor public art sculptures by Geoffrey Bartlett located within the ACT Magistrates Court.
j746-krni.pointname: Oyster is one of two indoor public art sculptures by Geoffrey Bartlett located within the ACT Magistrates Court.

j746-krni.Title: Patria es Humanidad (Our Country is Humanity)
j746-krni.Artist: Nelson Dominguez Cedeño (with the support of local artist Geoff Farquhar-Still)
j746-krni.Description: Rising from its base of gravel and stone, the peg symbolises the connections, unity and solidarity of the human family. Supported by the peg is a planet where ethnicities, cultures and religions, despite their differences, merge together in the essence of our human existence.
j746-krni.pointtype: Patria es Humanidad (Our Country is Humanity)
j746-krni.pointname: Rising from its base of gravel and stone, the peg symbolises the connections, unity and solidarity of the human family. Supported by the peg is a planet where ethnicities, cultures and religions, despite their differences, merge together in the essence of our human existence.

j746-krni.Title: Poet's Corner
j746-krni.Description: Poet's Corner is a collection of three bronze busts by Cathy Weiszmann of Canberra focussed Australian poets Judith Wright, A.D. Hope and David Campbell.
j746-krni.pointname: Poet's Corner is a collection of three bronze busts by Cathy Weiszmann of Canberra focussed Australian poets Judith Wright, A.D. Hope and David Campbell.

j746-krni.Title: Prime Minister John Curtin and Treasurer Ben Chifley, ca 1945
j746-krni.Description: This sculpture recreates an iconic photograph of John Curtin (1885-1945), Australia’s fourteenth Prime Minister (1941-45), and Treasurer Joseph Benedict (Ben) Chifley (1885-1951), who would become Australia’s sixteenth Prime Minister (1945-49). Curtin and Chifley routinely walked along this route to the Provisional (Old) Parliament House from the nearby Kurrajong Hotel - where Labor Members of Parliament generally stayed, while Parliament was sitting. Curtin and Chifley are two of Australia’s most respected Prime Ministers and they were strong supporters of the development of Canberra as the nation’s capital.
j746-krni.pointtype: Prime Minister John Curtin and Treasurer Ben Chifley, ca 1945
j746-krni.pointname: This sculpture recreates an iconic photograph of John Curtin (1885-1945), Australia’s fourteenth Prime Minister (1941-45), and Treasurer Joseph Benedict (Ben) Chifley (1885-1951), who would become Australia’s sixteenth Prime Minister (1945-49). Curtin and Chifley routinely walked along this route to the Provisional (Old) Parliament House from the nearby Kurrajong Hotel - where Labor Members of Parliament generally stayed, while Parliament was sitting. Curtin and Chifley are two of Australia’s most respected Prime Ministers and they were strong supporters of the development of Canberra as the nation’s capital.

j746-krni.Title: Private Poetry
j746-krni.Description: Private Poetry by Richard Tipping was purchased from Sculpture by the Sea in 2011, and has been erected as an adjunct to the Poets’ Corner installation in Garema Place.
j746-krni.pointname: Private Poetry by Richard Tipping was purchased from Sculpture by the Sea in 2011, and has been erected as an adjunct to the Poets’ Corner installation in Garema Place.

j746-krni.Title: Rain Pools
j746-krni.Description: Rain Pools is a series of granite discs that respond to the tranquillity of Lake Burley Griffin. The sculpture creates a calming environment for the patients, families and staff of Clare Holland House. They symbolise circles of support and the bonds of a common humanity.
j746-krni.pointname: Rain Pools is a series of granite discs that respond to the tranquillity of Lake Burley Griffin. The sculpture creates a calming environment for the patients, families and staff of Clare Holland House. They symbolise circles of support and the bonds of a common humanity.

j746-krni.Title: Reclamation: Culture, Spirit and Place
j746-krni.Description: Reclamation: Culture, Spirit and Place celebrates the survival of the spirit, and the courage and the dignity shown by the Ngunnawal people as they move forward into the future. The artwork consists of a ceramic tile mosaic set into the pavement and decorative metal panels which depict a variety of totemic animals and references to the Molonglo River.
j746-krni.pointname: Reclamation: Culture, Spirit and Place celebrates the survival of the spirit, and the courage and the dignity shown by the Ngunnawal people as they move forward into the future. The artwork consists of a ceramic tile mosaic set into the pavement and decorative metal panels which depict a variety of totemic animals and references to the Molonglo River.

j746-krni.Title: Red and Blue
j746-krni.Description: This sculpture uses an abstract language of colour, form, volume and plane to create a sense of tension and quiet strength. The artist has made a significant contribution to the development of Australian modern sculpture and has been exhibiting for close to 60 years.
j746-krni.pointname: This sculpture uses an abstract language of colour, form, volume and plane to create a sense of tension and quiet strength. The artist has made a significant contribution to the development of Australian modern sculpture and has been exhibiting for close to 60 years.

j746-krni.Title: Relic
j746-krni.Description: Relic is a bronze sentinal, an ancient figure borne from distant memory, standing at a nexus of both time and place. Located at the edge of the city and watching over a seat of learning, the sculpture evokes both power and purpose. Relic was the winner of the prestigious McClelland Sculpture Prize in 2007.
j746-krni.pointname: Relic is a bronze sentinal, an ancient figure borne from distant memory, standing at a nexus of both time and place. Located at the edge of the city and watching over a seat of learning, the sculpture evokes both power and purpose. Relic was the winner of the prestigious McClelland Sculpture Prize in 2007.

j746-krni.Title: Resilience
j746-krni.Description: Commissioned by Consolidated Builders Ltd, Resilience is on loan to the ACT Government. The location of this artwork is the result of a very successful collaboration between the ACT Government and the private developer, Consolidated Builders Ltd.
j746-krni.pointname: Commissioned by Consolidated Builders Ltd, Resilience is on loan to the ACT Government. The location of this artwork is the result of a very successful collaboration between the ACT Government and the private developer, Consolidated Builders Ltd.

j746-krni.Title: Resting Place of the Dragonfly
j746-krni.Description: Resting Place of the Dragonfly was exhibited in the 1989 Floriade Sculpture Project.In 2011 it was refurbished and relocated within Commonwealth Park.
j746-krni.pointname: Resting Place of the Dragonfly was exhibited in the 1989 Floriade Sculpture Project.In 2011 it was refurbished and relocated within Commonwealth Park.

j746-krni.Title: Running Lights
j746-krni.Description: Running Lights is a series of brightly-coloured columns that respond to Lake Ginninderra and its environment. They chime and sway, and in the evening they shine across the water.
j746-krni.pointname: Running Lights is a series of brightly-coloured columns that respond to Lake Ginninderra and its environment. They chime and sway, and in the evening they shine across the water.

j746-krni.Title: Sculpture No 23 (The Parcel)
j746-krni.Medium: Western Australian jade green marble, white marble and resin inlay (2003)
j746-krni.Description: Sculpture No 23 (The Parcel) is a carved illusion where an everyday object is transformed into and object of art. The artist has sculpted green and white marble to recreate a package with the creases and dents of a long journey. The contents are yet to be revealed.
j746-krni.pointname: Sculpture No 23 (The Parcel) is a carved illusion where an everyday object is transformed into and object of art. The artist has sculpted green and white marble to recreate a package with the creases and dents of a long journey. The contents are yet to be revealed.

j746-krni.Title: Sculptured Form
j746-krni.Description: This work was the winner of a competition that invited artists to represent the ‘metamorphosis of a typical natural Australian environment into complex development for urban use’. Hinder has created a commanding, beautifully fluid, plump work that belies its materials. By polishing the aluminum surface to a soft patina, and allowing it to bulge around the middle, the sculpture resembles a large soft heart, appearing to be made of several chambers but actually one connected and vital whole.
j746-krni.pointname: This work was the winner of a competition that invited artists to represent the ‘metamorphosis of a typical natural Australian environment into complex development for urban use’. Hinder has created a commanding, beautifully fluid, plump work that belies its materials. By polishing the aluminum surface to a soft patina, and allowing it to bulge around the middle, the sculpture resembles a large soft heart, appearing to be made of several chambers but actually one connected and vital whole.

j746-krni.Title: Seqvanae
j746-krni.Medium: Polished stainless steel and red fibreglass
j746-krni.Description: The work forms a gateway to the ACT Health Building and is rich with symbolic references to health and medicine. The work is a tribute to 'Seqvanae', Roman goddess of healing and includes red and silver crosses and a snake representing the Greek doctor 'Aesculapius'. Lettering on the work resembles an optometrist's eye test chart.
j746-krni.pointname: The work forms a gateway to the ACT Health Building and is rich with symbolic references to health and medicine. The work is a tribute to 'Seqvanae', Roman goddess of healing and includes red and silver crosses and a snake representing the Greek doctor 'Aesculapius'. Lettering on the work resembles an optometrist's eye test chart.

j746-krni.Title: Sir Robert Menzies
j746-krni.Description: The ACT Government commissioned Sir Robert Menzies and another artwork by Peter Corlett to celebrate and acknowledge former Prime Ministers that significantly supported the development of Canberra.
j746-krni.pointname: The ACT Government commissioned Sir Robert Menzies and another artwork by Peter Corlett to celebrate and acknowledge former Prime Ministers that significantly supported the development of Canberra.

j746-krni.Title: Sky Shard Above the In Between
j746-krni.Description: A folded form balanced on a point, painted blue. The artwork amplifies and gives form to the architectural forms of the building on one side and of the sculpture and the natural forms of the trees on the other.
j746-krni.pointtype: Sky Shard Above the In Between
j746-krni.pointname: A folded form balanced on a point, painted blue. The artwork amplifies and gives form to the architectural forms of the building on one side and of the sculpture and the natural forms of the trees on the other.

j746-krni.Title: Soccer Players
j746-krni.Artist: Bev Hogg, Elizabeth Patterson and Mike McGregor
j746-krni.Medium: Stainless steel armature with a coloured concrete shell
j746-krni.Description: Commissioned by the Village Building Company, this artwork consists of three lifesize children playing a game of soccer.
j746-krni.pointname: Commissioned by the Village Building Company, this artwork consists of three lifesize children playing a game of soccer.

j746-krni.Title: Statue of Confucius
j746-krni.Artist: Jiaxiang Stone Carving Studio of Shandong (山東嘉祥杏花石雕厂) Established 1910
j746-krni.Description: Confucius, a Chinese philosopher and teacher who lived in fifth century BC, has had a profound influence on Chinese culture and thought. This sculpture was carved in the birth place of Confucius, Qufu, Shandong Province, China. The sculpture was gifted to the people of Canberra by the Australian Confucius Research Society in association with the Canberra Chinese Community Preparatory Committee of the Statue of Confucius to celebrate the tenth anniversary of the signing of the Sister City Agreement between Canberra and Beijing.
j746-krni.pointname: Confucius, a Chinese philosopher and teacher who lived in fifth century BC, has had a profound influence on Chinese culture and thought. This sculpture was carved in the birth place of Confucius, Qufu, Shandong Province, China. The sculpture was gifted to the people of Canberra by the Australian Confucius Research Society in association with the Canberra Chinese Community Preparatory Committee of the Statue of Confucius to celebrate the tenth anniversary of the signing of the Sister City Agreement between Canberra and Beijing.

j746-krni.Title: Stepping Out
j746-krni.Description: This life size, realist female figure, replete with hat and handbag has become a loved local at the Hughes Shopping Centre.
j746-krni.pointname: This life size, realist female figure, replete with hat and handbag has become a loved local at the Hughes Shopping Centre.

j746-krni.Title: Sweet Justice
j746-krni.Medium: Water sculpture with glass tiles, fibre optic lighting and air
j746-krni.Description: The work is located near the law courts and many legal offices and combines water, light and air. The word ‘sweet’ appears under water on a tiled surface.
j746-krni.pointname: The work is located near the law courts and many legal offices and combines water, light and air. The word ‘sweet’ appears under water on a tiled surface.

j746-krni.Title: The Ability to Imagine
j746-krni.Description: This rusted steel sculpture portrays a poetic journey of the spirit. A figure, travel case in hand, contemplates a voyage that while imaginary does not appear to be without effort. The sculpture is one of a series of works through which the artist explores the concept of a journey as a metaphor for the search for meaning in life.
j746-krni.pointname: This rusted steel sculpture portrays a poetic journey of the spirit. A figure, travel case in hand, contemplates a voyage that while imaginary does not appear to be without effort. The sculpture is one of a series of works through which the artist explores the concept of a journey as a metaphor for the search for meaning in life.

j746-krni.Title: The Big Little Man
j746-krni.Description: The Big Little Man is a whimsical sculpture that appears both larger and smaller than life at the same time.
j746-krni.pointname: The Big Little Man is a whimsical sculpture that appears both larger and smaller than life at the same time.

j746-krni.Title: The Canberra Times Fountain
j746-krni.Medium: Tube and rod fabricated stainless steel
j746-krni.Description: The Canberra Times Fountain by Bob Woodward was commissioned by Federal Capital Press in 1976 and installed as a gift to the people of Canberra in 1979. This dramatic fountain marks the intersection of Ainslie Avenue with City Walk.
j746-krni.pointname: The Canberra Times Fountain by Bob Woodward was commissioned by Federal Capital Press in 1976 and installed as a gift to the people of Canberra in 1979. This dramatic fountain marks the intersection of Ainslie Avenue with City Walk.

j746-krni.Title: The Fourth Pillar
j746-krni.Description: The work features evocative blue neon phrases which stretch down a number of columns and are visible from the various mezzanine floors within the ACT Magistrates Court. By using lyrical everyday terms which have specific legal meanings the artist intended that the work would soften the experience for people visiting and working in this building.
j746-krni.pointname: The work features evocative blue neon phrases which stretch down a number of columns and are visible from the various mezzanine floors within the ACT Magistrates Court. By using lyrical everyday terms which have specific legal meanings the artist intended that the work would soften the experience for people visiting and working in this building.

j746-krni.Title: The Glebe
j746-krni.Artist: Hew Chee Fong and L M Noonan
j746-krni.Description: Inspired by Glebe House, previously located on this site, the Glebe is made from a single block of grandee granite, segmented into house shaped blocks to represent European settlement of the area and the sub-division of the original Glebe allotment of 119 acres.
j746-krni.pointname: Inspired by Glebe House, previously located on this site, the Glebe is made from a single block of grandee granite, segmented into house shaped blocks to represent European settlement of the area and the sub-division of the original Glebe allotment of 119 acres.

j746-krni.Title: The Goongarline
j746-krni.Description: The Goongarline draws inspiration from Gungahlin's rocky hills or 'Goongarline' as they were called by local Indigenous people at the time of European settlement.
j746-krni.pointname: The Goongarline draws inspiration from Gungahlin's rocky hills or 'Goongarline' as they were called by local Indigenous people at the time of European settlement.

j746-krni.Title: The Master's Voice
j746-krni.Description: On the edge of City Walk is a concrete wall which houses a soundscape. The Master’s Voice ‘...trips up passers-by, induces double-takes, [and] private puzzled glances...' (Mitchell Whitelaw in Real Time Magazine #46, 2001).
j746-krni.pointname: On the edge of City Walk is a concrete wall which houses a soundscape. The Master’s Voice ‘...trips up passers-by, induces double-takes, [and] private puzzled glances...' (Mitchell Whitelaw in Real Time Magazine #46, 2001).

j746-krni.Title: The Meeting Place
j746-krni.Description: The Meeting Place is made up of seven layered glass figures installed on a glass wall.
j746-krni.pointname: The Meeting Place is made up of seven layered glass figures installed on a glass wall.

j746-krni.Title: The Other Side of Midnight
j746-krni.Description: This whimsical artwork consists of a painted doll with a decorated carousel dog on either side, linking closely with the much loved Civic carousel.
j746-krni.pointname: This whimsical artwork consists of a painted doll with a decorated carousel dog on either side, linking closely with the much loved Civic carousel.

j746-krni.Title: The View From Here
j746-krni.Description: The artist is renowned for a series of relief artworks redepicting illustrations from the ‘World Book of Knowledge'.
j746-krni.pointname: The artist is renowned for a series of relief artworks redepicting illustrations from the ‘World Book of Knowledge'.

j746-krni.Title: The World Peace Flame Monument
j746-krni.Description: This monument represents the steps each person takes for peace. Bogong moths are shown being drawn to a flame by Ngunnawal artist Jim Williams. Bogong moths migrate through this area each year and were a traditional food source for local aboriginal people.
j746-krni.pointname: This monument represents the steps each person takes for peace. Bogong moths are shown being drawn to a flame by Ngunnawal artist Jim Williams. Bogong moths migrate through this area each year and were a traditional food source for local aboriginal people.

j746-krni.Title: Thespis
j746-krni.Description: This work has recently been relocated to the refurbished foyer of the Canberra Theatre Centre. Thespis was the legendary originator of Greek tragedy.
j746-krni.pointname: This work has recently been relocated to the refurbished foyer of the Canberra Theatre Centre. Thespis was the legendary originator of Greek tragedy.

j746-krni.Title: Toku
j746-krni.Description: The ACT Government commissioned Toku by Japanese artist Shinki Kato to celebrate the 1300th anniversary of Japan’s ancient capital, Nara.
j746-krni.pointname: The ACT Government commissioned Toku by Japanese artist Shinki Kato to celebrate the 1300th anniversary of Japan’s ancient capital, Nara.

j746-krni.Title: Touching Lightly
j746-krni.Description: Touching Lightly was funded in partnership by the ACT Government, ActewAGL and the ACTEW Corporation and the Land Development Agency.
j746-krni.pointname: Touching Lightly was funded in partnership by the ACT Government, ActewAGL and the ACTEW Corporation and the Land Development Agency.

j746-krni.Title: Tree of Knowledge
j746-krni.Description: This sculpture honours Australian writers and the part played by landscape in our literature. The streets of Garran are named after Australian writers and members of the Garran family. Local stone forms the base of this cast bronze sculpture which reflects playfully on relationships between human knowledge and our native landscape.
j746-krni.pointname: This sculpture honours Australian writers and the part played by landscape in our literature. The streets of Garran are named after Australian writers and members of the Garran family. Local stone forms the base of this cast bronze sculpture which reflects playfully on relationships between human knowledge and our native landscape.

j746-krni.Title: Twilight
j746-krni.Medium: Formed concrete, street lamps and brass lettering.
j746-krni.Description: Twilight is an evocative and enigmatic public artwork that exists between sculpture, architecture, and landscape design. It evokes qualities of a memorial, monument and meeting place. Its form echoes the geometry and symbolism of Canberra's urban plan.
j746-krni.pointname: Twilight is an evocative and enigmatic public artwork that exists between sculpture, architecture, and landscape design. It evokes qualities of a memorial, monument and meeting place. Its form echoes the geometry and symbolism of Canberra's urban plan.

j746-krni.Title: Two Legged Marsupial
j746-krni.Description: Two Legged Marsupial is one of two indoor public art sculptures by Geoffrey Bartlett located within the ACT Magistrates Court.
j746-krni.pointname: Two Legged Marsupial is one of two indoor public art sculptures by Geoffrey Bartlett located within the ACT Magistrates Court.

j746-krni.Title: Two to Tango
j746-krni.Description: Two to Tango is two curvy linear metal forms that can be viewed as subtly referring to couples or plant shoots reflecting the growth and rise of the city centre and its changing demographic. The blue colour of the forms echo the blue skies of Canberra.
j746-krni.pointname: Two to Tango is two curvy linear metal forms that can be viewed as subtly referring to couples or plant shoots reflecting the growth and rise of the city centre and its changing demographic. The blue colour of the forms echo the blue skies of Canberra.

j746-krni.Title: Untitled (Andrew Townsend and Suzie Bleach, 1997)
j746-krni.Description: This lively mosaic provides a welcoming entry to the Family Health Centre.
j746-krni.pointname: This lively mosaic provides a welcoming entry to the Family Health Centre.

j746-krni.Title: Untitled (Andrew Townsend and Suzie Bleach, 2000)
j746-krni.Description: Four large silhouettes are suspended above Koomari indoor pool: a person, a comet, a ring and a flower. The sculpture and its reflections create a unique experience for those that use the pool. The sculpture also works as a sound dampener in the pool area.
j746-krni.pointname: Four large silhouettes are suspended above Koomari indoor pool: a person, a comet, a ring and a flower. The sculpture and its reflections create a unique experience for those that use the pool. The sculpture also works as a sound dampener in the pool area.

j746-krni.Title: Untitled (Bert Flugelman, 1979)
j746-krni.Description: A series of highly-polished metal cubes appear to tumble across Margaret Timpson Park in the heart of the Belconnen Town Centre. This is one of three works by this celebrated Australian artist in Canberra: one work is permanently displayed in the Sculpture Garden at The National Gallery of Australia and another conceptual work is buried in the earth at Commonwealth Park.
j746-krni.pointname: A series of highly-polished metal cubes appear to tumble across Margaret Timpson Park in the heart of the Belconnen Town Centre. This is one of three works by this celebrated Australian artist in Canberra: one work is permanently displayed in the Sculpture Garden at The National Gallery of Australia and another conceptual work is buried in the earth at Commonwealth Park.

j746-krni.Title: Untitled (Frank Hinder, 1963)
j746-krni.Description: This work by the renowned modernist artist Frank Hinder is one of the most subtle artworks in the city centre. Created as part of the building, the vaulted tiled ceiling is a remarkable blend of form, tone and colour. Monaro Mall established this precinct as a hub of retail activity in Civic from the early 1960s.
j746-krni.pointname: This work by the renowned modernist artist Frank Hinder is one of the most subtle artworks in the city centre. Created as part of the building, the vaulted tiled ceiling is a remarkable blend of form, tone and colour. Monaro Mall established this precinct as a hub of retail activity in Civic from the early 1960s.

j746-krni.Title: Untitled (G Duncan, B and F Waterman, 1985)
j746-krni.Artist: G Duncan, B and F Waterman
j746-krni.Description: This ceramic wall mural depicts native Australian flora and fauna and stretches from the outside of the Perpetual Building into the foyer.
j746-krni.pointtype: Untitled (G Duncan, B and F Waterman, 1985)
j746-krni.pointname: This ceramic wall mural depicts native Australian flora and fauna and stretches from the outside of the Perpetual Building into the foyer.

j746-krni.Title: Untitled (Gerald and Margo Lewers, 1965)
j746-krni.Medium: Four piece wall sculpture, cast copper
j746-krni.Description: The original maquette for this work was designed and fabricated by Gerald Lewers, and developed and executed by Margo Lewers after his death. This 17 metre long sculpture includes a fulcrum and two weights symbolizing the Reserve Bank’s role in balancing the economy.
j746-krni.pointname: The original maquette for this work was designed and fabricated by Gerald Lewers, and developed and executed by Margo Lewers after his death. This 17 metre long sculpture includes a fulcrum and two weights symbolizing the Reserve Bank’s role in balancing the economy.

j746-krni.Title: Untitled (Jean-Pierre Rives, 2008)
j746-krni.Description: This untitled abstract artwork was donated to the ACT Public Art Collection by Leighton Properties.
j746-krni.pointname: This untitled abstract artwork was donated to the ACT Public Art Collection by Leighton Properties.

j746-krni.Title: Untitled (Keiko Amenomori-Schmeisser, 1999)
j746-krni.Description: Keiko Amenomori-Schmeisser's etched ink design adds texture to the outdoor projection screen in Garema Place.
j746-krni.pointname: Keiko Amenomori-Schmeisser's etched ink design adds texture to the outdoor projection screen in Garema Place.

j746-krni.Title: Untitled (Paul Piesley, 2001)
j746-krni.Medium: Silk screen printed image on bus shelter roofs
j746-krni.Description: This integrated work is screenprinted on the awnings of the city centre's bus platforms. Screenprinted footprints provide shade whilst representing the day to day pedestrian traffic in the area, reminding people of the many others who have passed through here before them.
j746-krni.pointname: This integrated work is screenprinted on the awnings of the city centre's bus platforms. Screenprinted footprints provide shade whilst representing the day to day pedestrian traffic in the area, reminding people of the many others who have passed through here before them.

j746-krni.Title: Untitled (S Maritti, 1967)
j746-krni.Description: This work is integrated with the building façade and was designed to complement the Commonwealth Bank building’s architecture.
j746-krni.pointname: This work is integrated with the building façade and was designed to complement the Commonwealth Bank building’s architecture.

j746-krni.Title: Vessel of (Horti)cultural Plenty
j746-krni.Description: The Vessel holds abstracted flowers that are illuminated at night and move with the breeze.
j746-krni.pointname: The Vessel holds abstracted flowers that are illuminated at night and move with the breeze.

j746-krni.Title: We Are Fishes
j746-krni.Medium: Galvanised steel, cast black patinated aluminium, hollow form copper sheet with green patination
j746-krni.Description: A pair of wind vanes in the shape of fish appear to swim through the air between the Tuggeranong Arts Centre and Lake Tuggeranong. One fish is cast black patinated aluminium, the other hollow form copper sheet with green patination. The work reflects life in the adjacent lake and plays on the nautical architecture of the Arts Centre building.
j746-krni.pointname: A pair of wind vanes in the shape of fish appear to swim through the air between the Tuggeranong Arts Centre and Lake Tuggeranong. One fish is cast black patinated aluminium, the other hollow form copper sheet with green patination. The work reflects life in the adjacent lake and plays on the nautical architecture of the Arts Centre building.

j746-krni.Title: wide brown land
j746-krni.Artist: Marcus Tatton, Futago and Chris Viney
j746-krni.Description: This artwork celebrates Dorothea Mackellar's popular Australian poem My Country which was written in 1908. The sculptural forms that make up the work are inspired by the cursive style of Mackellar's own hand-writing. The artwork frames a wide vista that stretches across the National Arboretum Canberra to the hills that mark Canberra's western and southern boundaries.
j746-krni.pointname: This artwork celebrates Dorothea Mackellar's popular Australian poem My Country which was written in 1908. The sculptural forms that make up the work are inspired by the cursive style of Mackellar's own hand-writing. The artwork frames a wide vista that stretches across the National Arboretum Canberra to the hills that mark Canberra's western and southern boundaries.

j746-krni.Title: Wind Sculpture
j746-krni.Description: This work is a fine example of a style of kinetic sculpture popular through the late 1970’s. It marks the entry to 'the Boulevard' development which was anticipated to be an international retail precinct for Canberra. Whilst the Boulevard never fulfilled this promise, the first floor open air plaza is a fascinating example of 1970’s planning for public space.
j746-krni.pointname: This work is a fine example of a style of kinetic sculpture popular through the late 1970’s. It marks the entry to 'the Boulevard' development which was anticipated to be an international retail precinct for Canberra. Whilst the Boulevard never fulfilled this promise, the first floor open air plaza is a fascinating example of 1970’s planning for public space.

j746-krni.Title: Winds of Light
j746-krni.Description: This sculpture is the last public artwork of the well known artist, Peter Blizzard. His practice was unique in his use of contrasting materials as an ongoing investigation into the relationship of nature to the human spirit. He believed that we should venerate and respect what we have. This work is the artist’s response to the effect that grandeur, colour, light, texture and form within the natural landscape have on the wellbeing of the human spirit.
j746-krni.pointname: This sculpture is the last public artwork of the well known artist, Peter Blizzard. His practice was unique in his use of contrasting materials as an ongoing investigation into the relationship of nature to the human spirit. He believed that we should venerate and respect what we have. This work is the artist’s response to the effect that grandeur, colour, light, texture and form within the natural landscape have on the wellbeing of the human spirit.

j746-krni.Title: Windstone - A Trail of a Cloud
j746-krni.Description: This sculpture combines materials that have very different visual and tactile qualities. The solidity and surface detail of natural granite is a sharp contrast to the ethereal, mirrored surface of stainless steel. Windstone brings a sensation of the material and immaterial together in one object. The artist's work has been described as an exploration of the experience of land and sky, and the concious and unconcious.
j746-krni.pointtype: Windstone - A Trail of a Cloud
j746-krni.pointname: This sculpture combines materials that have very different visual and tactile qualities. The solidity and surface detail of natural granite is a sharp contrast to the ethereal, mirrored surface of stainless steel. Windstone brings a sensation of the material and immaterial together in one object. The artist's work has been described as an exploration of the experience of land and sky, and the concious and unconcious.

j746-krni.Title: Woden Flood Memorial
j746-krni.Description: The memorial is dedicated to the memory of seven young people, including four children, who lost their lives in the Woden Floods on Australia Day 1971.
j746-krni.pointname: The memorial is dedicated to the memory of seven young people, including four children, who lost their lives in the Woden Floods on Australia Day 1971.

j746-krni.Title: Young Eagle
j746-krni.Description: This bronze sculpture of a young eagle looks keenly down from its perch into the busy activity of Bunda Street. The sculpture evokes the strength, optimism and freedom of youth - a spirit that can be embraced at any age.
j746-krni.pointname: This bronze sculpture of a young eagle looks keenly down from its perch into the busy activity of Bunda Street. The sculpture evokes the strength, optimism and freedom of youth - a spirit that can be embraced at any age.
